title: Function reference
text:
Functions to help you survive in Vancouver.



clothing.calculate_warmth_score
Calculate a warmth score to determine appropriate clothing for Vancouver campus commute.

title: Function reference
text:
Functions to help you survive in Vancouver.



clothing.calculate_warmth_score
Calculate a warmth score to determine appropriate clothing for Vancouver campus commute.

title: Contributing
text:
Contributions of all kinds are welcome here, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.


You can contribute in many ways, for example:

Report bugs
Fix Bugs
Implement Features
Write Documentation
Submit Feedback



Report bugs at https://github.com/ilyamusabirov/vancouver_survival/issues.
If you are reporting a bug, please follow the template guidelines. The more detailed your report, the easier and thus faster we can help you.



Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything labelled with bug and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it. When you decide to work on such an issue, please assign yourself to it and add a comment that you’ll be working on that, too. If you see another issue without the help wanted label, just post a comment, the maintainers are usually happy for any support that they can get.



Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything labelled with enhancement and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it. As for fixing bugs, please assign yourself to the issue and add a comment that you’ll be working on that, too. If another enhancement catches your fancy, but it doesn’t have the help wanted label, just post a comment, the maintainers are usually happy for any support that they can get.



vancouver-survival could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official documentation, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such. Just open an issue to let us know what you will be working on so that we can provide you with guidance.



The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/ilyamusabirov/vancouver_survival/issues. If your feedback fits the format of one of the issue templates, please use that. Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project and everybody has limited time.




Ready to contribute? Here’s how to set up vancouver-survival for local development.

Fork the https://github.com/ilyamusabirov/vancouver_survival repository on GitHub.
Clone your fork locally (if you want to work locally)
git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/vancouver_survival.git
Install hatch.
Create a branch for local development using the default branch (typically main) as a starting point. Use fix or feat as a prefix for your branch name.
git checkout main
git checkout -b fix-name-of-your-bugfix
Now you can make your changes locally.
When you’re done making changes, apply the quality assurance tools and check that your changes pass our test suite. This is all included with tox
hatch run test:run
Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub. Please use semantic commit messages.
git add .
git commit -m "fix: summarize your changes"
git push -u origin fix-name-of-your-bugfix
Open the link displayed in the message when pushing your new branch in order to submit a pull request.



Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

The pull request should include tests.
If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring.
Your pull request will automatically be checked by the full test suite. It needs to pass all of them before it can be considered for merging.

title: clothing.calculate_warmth_score
text:
clothing.calculate_warmth_score(
    temp_celsius,
    wind_speed_kmh,
    is_waiting_for_bus,
)
Calculate a warmth score to determine appropriate clothing for Vancouver campus commute.
The score increases with colder conditions, accounting for temperature, wind chill, and whether you’re stationary or moving. Higher scores indicate colder perceived conditions requiring more insulation.











Name
Type
Description
Default




temp_celsius
float
Temperature in Celsius. Must be >= -273.15 (absolute zero).
required


wind_speed_kmh
float
Wind speed in kilometers per hour. Must be non-negative.
required


is_waiting_for_bus
bool
True if wait for a bus expected (increases warmth score by 2 because of inactivity), False if actively walking/biking.
required














Name
Type
Description





float
Warmth score indicating clothing needs, for example: + 1: T-shirt weather (>10°C after wind chill) + 3: Light jacket (0-10°C after wind chill) + 10: Arctic parka (<-20°C after wind chill)














Name
Type
Description





ValueError
If wind_speed_kmh is negative (physics violation). If temp_celsius is below -273.15 (below absolute zero).






Wind chill reduces effective temperature by 1°C per 10 km/h of wind.
